Programa Institucional de Fomento a la Investigación, Desarrollo e Innovación Universidad Tecnológica Metropolitana Ignacio Valdivieso # 2409, San Joaqui Santiago Chile Herein we present a detailed mechanistic investigation of Z-selective ROMP of norbornadiene (NBD) with MAP-based catalyst 3a-b by DFT (M06) calculations. The studied catalytic reaction mechanism include the initiation, interconversion, and propagation stages with anti and syn NBD olefin attacks. In the initiation, we found the inversion of the metal center from the (R) configuration in the initial reactant to the (S). Further, we found that the olefin attack anti is kinetically more favorable than syn . Following this, we found that the stabilization order of the ring-opening species (ROS) is vital for the Z-selectivity due to the 3a-b-anti-1/2-cis/trans producing cis-polymers, and 3a-b-syn-1/2-trans produces trans-polymers. Furthermore, the 3a-anti-2-cis+syn pathways form cis-syndiotactic polymers that must overcome 30.8 kcal mol−1, respectively, during the propagation stage. Finally, the [2+2] cycloaddition of the propagation stages determines the reaction rate, which is essential for producing stereoregular polymers. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Density functional theory Ring-opening metathesis polymerization MAP-catalyst Stereoregular polymers Z-selectivity 1 Introduction Olefin Metathesis (OM) is an essential organic synthetic strategy used to convert alkenes [1]. These conversions are often accomplished using the Grubbs catalyst, which is based on ruthenium complexes, and the Schrock catalyst of molybdenum and tungsten complexes [2–7]. Due to the large array of olefins, numerous metathesis reactions are achievable. The most prominent are (i) Cross metathesis (CM), (ii) Ring-closing metathesis (RCM) [8] produces cyclic olefins (iii) Ring-opening metathesis polymerization (ROMP) [9] Scheme 1 . These reactions are widely recognized as an essential and efficient technique for generating various biological products [10] and materials science, [11–13] including medicines, natural products, and innovative polymers, to mention a few. It is growing rapidly and is recognized for developing polymeric materials with specific tacticity, stereo, and regioselectivity [14–16]. In CM and ROMP reactions, the trans olefins are obtained by thermodynamically control, while cis-isomeric olefins are kinetically preferred. Thus, designing an appropriate catalyst is crucial in Z-selective CM and ROMP reactions. In this regard, the ROMP reaction with norbornadiene (NBD) olefin is the most experimentally explored. As shown in Fig. 1 , this reaction yields polymers with four stereoregular structures (cis/trans-isotactic and cis/trans-syndiotactic), each one having identical and alternating chiral carbons configurations [17]. ROMP with Mo-Schrock catalyst has been extensively studied due to their remarkable stereo- and enantioselectivity, and tolerance to various functional groups [15,18]. As illustrated in Fig. 2 , the conventional Mo catalysts [Mo(NAr)(=CHCMe2Ph)(OR)2] 1a-c (R=tbu (a) CMe2(CF3) (b), CMe(CF3)2 (c)) with imido alkylidene and alkoxy groups as primary and ancillary ligands, respectively [17,19,20], showed activity toward trans-syndiotactic polymers when 1a was used. When 1b-c was used, it showed potential activity to cis-isotactic polymers. Additionally, the cis-isotactic polymers were produced using [Mo(NAr)(=CHCMe2Ph)(diolate)2] 2 with biphenolate or binaphatholate as alkoxy groups [19]. After, Schrock complexes known as MAP catalysts [21], (by MonoAlkoxyde Pyrrolide) [Mo(NR)(=CHCMe2Ph)(Pyr)(O-(2,6-Trip-C6H3))] 3a-b (NR=Ad(a), Ar(b)), can produce extremely stereoregular or cis-syndiotactic polymers [22]. Likewise, Buchmeiser et al. have recently synthesized a new Mo catalyst [Mo(NAr)(=CHCMe2Ph)(NHC)(OTf)2] with N-heterocycle carbene 4 that exhibited excellent stereoselectivity in cyclopolymerization [23–25]. They have also successfully synthesized the first-ever reported cationic Mo-based alkylidyne NHC compounds of [Mo(CC6H4-p-OMe)(IMes)(OCMe(CF3)2)2][B(ArF)4] (IMes = 1,3-dimesitylimidazol-2-ylidene) 5 demonstrating excellent catalytic activity, productivity, and tolerance towards the various functional group [26]. Other catalysts can also induce stereoregular polymers. For instance, Grubbs catalyst 6 [27] and tBu-cyclometalated catalyst 7 showed a high yield to cis-syndiotactic polymers [28,29]. Hoveyda and colleagues synthesized Ru catechothiolate and S-monodentate complex 8-9 that is highly selective to cis-syndiotactic polymers [30–35]. Immobilizing complexes on solid supports is a typical method for addressing some of the problems associated with homogeneous catalysis. Several reports have used various supports to immobilize Ru olefin metathesis catalysts. Recently, novel catalysis inspired from 8, the silica-supported ruthenium-based complexes immobilized by aryl thiolate 10 have shown promising Z-selective and stereoretentive in olefin metathesis reactions [36]. On the other hand, vanadium and tungsten catalysts are also equivalent to those Mo and Ru catalysts for ROMP as 11-12 [37–39]. These catalysts are also tolerant of different functional groups, and the stability of the active intermediates depends on the size and electron-donating behaviors of the imido and phosphine group. To achieve better stereoselective and tacticity in ROMP, it is necessary to develop innovative catalysts. The aforementioned catalysts performs with Chauvin's general mechanism of alkene metathesis. As shown in Scheme 2 , it involves four steps: (i) alkene coordination (AC), (ii) [2+2] cycloaddition (CA), (iii) [2+2] cycloreversion (CR), and (iv) alkene de-coordination (AdC). In particular, CM generates an active species and a new olefin in the initiation step, while the ROMP uniquely produces a ring-opening species (ROS) [40,41]. Studies on Z-selective catalyst 6 have revealed that the Side pathway is favored in alkene coordination [42–44] due to the steric hindrance between the catalyst and incoming olefin [35]. It has been proposed that the inversion of the metal center conformation during the forward metathesis step is the most crucial for the formation of stereoregular polymers with catalyst 3 [14,15,17,21,45,46]. For ROMP, eight reaction pathways has been proposed: a cis syndiotactic polymer can be formed if both the starting reactant and the incoming species are anti-conformation. The resulting ROS can undergo a rotameric change, producing a syn-conformer and a highly stereoregular trans-syndiotactic polymer (Fig. 3 ) [14,15]. Furthermore, two distinct alternate pathways are obtained. when the syn-specie starting reactant is considered, Finally, the second incoming olefins react with the ROS, opening up four additional reaction pathways. Therefore, explore the mechanism is crucial for the understanding the ROMP process, because the reactivity of 3, particularly, the propagation stage has not been explored in detail. It is important to emphasize that only a limited number of computational researches have been performed on the effect of Mo and Ru-based catalysts on ROMP. Poater et al. [47] investigated the rotational barrier for the syn/anti interconversion of simplified [Mo(Ad) (=CHR)(X)(Y)] with X and Y = alkyl, alkoxy, and siloxy, and they found excellent agreement with the experimental results. In 2014, a mechanistic study of ROMP with substituted cyclooctenes was carried out using the MAP catalysts 3. The catalyst's Z-selectivity can be attributed to the large size of the monoaryloxide ligand and the inversion of the configuration of these catalysts [48]. Meanwhile, Houk and Grubbs [49] observed that the rotational barriers of cyclometalated Ru-catalysts 6 ranging from 6.1 to 9.9 kcal mol−1, and cycloaddition barriers cis-syndiotactic propagation species are found to be the found lowest (7.2 kcal mol−1) [28]. Podewitz et al. [50] demonstrated a similar strategy for increasing the E‑Selectivity of the ROMP using molybdenum-based carbene complexes. Finally, the ROMP with 7 has explained the effect of the steric hindrance that allows a chain-end control of the tacticity of the produced polymers [31]. It is important to emphasize that the DFT investigation on ROMP using Mo and Ru-based catalysts is still limited. Thus, we have explored the whole mechanism of the ROMP with NBD reaction, including (i) initiation, (ii) ring-opening species interconversion, and (iii) propagation steps, using a Mo-based MAP model catalyst 3 (NR=Ad(a), Ar(b)). In the propagation step, we have investigated eight reaction pathways that may generate cis/trans-isotactic and cis/trans-syndiotactic polymers. This research aims to understand better the structural, thermodynamic, and kinetic parameters that influence the synthesis of stereoregular cis-syndiotactic polymers using MAP catalysts. 2 Computational details All calculations have been performed by the density functional theory (DFT) approach, using the Gaussian 16 program [51]. Molecular geometries were fully optimized using the global hybrid meta-GGA M06 exchange-correlation functional [52]. This functional includes noncovalent forces that provide good quality results on the olefin metathesis reaction [53,54]. The molybdenum core electrons were described by quasi-relativistic effective pseudopotentials (RECPs) developed by the Stuttgart group. The so-called MWB28 [55,56] replaces the 28 inner electrons with an effective nonlocal potential. The resting electrons were described with the associated (8s7p6d)/[6s5p3d] basis set, augmented with an f-type polarization function [57]. The other elements, such as C, H, N, O, and F, were represented by the 6-31+G(d,p) basis sets [58]. The nature of all the located, stationary points has been verified by vibrational analysis to ensure their nature as intermediate or transition structures. We confirmed the nature of the reactants and products connected to all the located transition structures by applying the eigenvector, corresponding to the imaginary frequency with the located transition structure, and performing the subsequent optimization of the resulting structure. Thermal contributions were employed for determining the enthalpy and Gibbs energy (G) for the initiation step using the harmonic oscillator and rigid rotor models, as implemented in the Gaussian 16 package at a pressure of 1 atm and 298 K. For the propagation step, an entropy correction proposed by Martin et.al. [59] was employed. A high pressure (p = 1254 atm) is used in the translational entropy to represent the liquid state and avoid the overestimation [60–62]. Solvent effects are included through the SMD continuum model [63] considering the dielectric constant of toluene and dichloromethane, solvents employed experimentally. Energetic correction is obtained from single point calculations, at the basis set of optimized geometries, with the larger 6-311+G(d,p) basis sets for C, N, O, H, F (Gsolv). Finally, all our results are expressed in G = G+ ΔGsolv. 3 Results and discussion We have analyzed the ROMP of NBD reactivity with molybdenum alkylidene complexes 3 (NR=Ad(a), Ar(b)) [21] to gain insight into the catalytic stages: initiation, interconversion, and propagation. This study aims to uncover the processes that underpin polymer iso/syndiotactic and Z-selectivity. We have focused on the reaction mechanisms described in Scheme 2 and Fig. 3. Initiation: A model of 3a-b was used in the initiation stage of the reaction. Here, the carbene bond (Mo=CHCMe2Ph) is reduced to its most straightforward form (Mo=CH2), and the substituents Trip= 2,4,6-i-Pr3C6H2 were converted from isopropyl to isomethyl groups (Trip'=2,4,6-i-Me3C6H2), but the main ligands, Ad=1-adamantyl and Ar=2,6-i-Pr2C6H3 are preserved. These geometries were optimized, obtaining that the NR ligand is planar to the Mo=CH2 for 3a (dihedral angle C-C-N-Mo=−14º) while is perpendicular for 3b (dihedral angle C=C-N-Mo=−75.5º) due to repulsive interactions between the NR ligand and the aromatic groups with Trip (See Fig. S1). Also, we found that the initial reactive for 3a-b can exhibit (S) and (R) conformers. The calculated energy values show that in toluene (S) is more stable than (R) with 1.0 kcal mol−1 for 3a and 4.1 kcal mol−1 for 3b, while if dichloromethane is used, (S) is 7.5 and 4.5 kcal mol−1 more stable than (R) for 3a and 3b, respectively which suggests that the conformers are easily interconverted between each other in toluene (Fig. 4 ). The more stable initial reactive 3a-b were studied before anti and syn olefin attacks. (See Fig. 4 for 3a and Fig. S1 for 3b) The optimized intermediate and transition structures of 3a + anti, 3a + syn, 3b + anti , and 3b + syn , are illustrated in Fig. 5, Fig. S2, Fig. S3, and Fig. S4, respectively. The Gibbs energies values of intermediate and transition structures are summarized in Table 1 for toluene and Table S1 for dichloromethane. The results show that the initiation step is favorable for forming ROS. It is to be noted that the rate determinant step is the [2+2] cycloaddition (CA) with energy barriers of 25.8, 35.3, 27.7 and 34.1 kcal mol−1 for 3a + anti and 3a + syn, 3b + anti and 3b + syn , respectively. These high energy barriers are associated with the geometrical rearrangements from the trigonal pyramid of a 3a-b-initial reactive to pseudo trigonal bipyramidal 3a-b-MCy metallacyclobutane intermediate. A significant shift in the angle O-Mo-N from 117–120ᵒ for 3a-b-AC, 138–144o for 3a-b-CA, and 172–159o for 3a-b-MCy, indicating structural rearrangements have occurred. Additionally, the inversion of the metal center from the (R) configuration in the 3a-b initial reactant to the (S) configuration in the 3a-b ROS proposed by Schrock is confirmed (Scheme 3 ). The results show that 3a-b+anti is kinetically more favorable than 3a-b+syn . In particular, 3a-anti-CA is 9.5 kcal mol−1 more stable than 3a-syn-CA, and 3b-anti-CA is 6.4 kcal mol−1 more stable than 3b-syn-CA. Moreover, 3a-anti and 3a-syn are more favored thermodynamically than 3b-anti and 3b-syn , which may shed light on the greater reactivity of 3a toward cis-syndiotactic polymer. Similar tendencies were obtained using dichloromethane, the 3a-(3b) anti-CA 10.2 (5.2) kcal mol−1 more stable than 3a-(3b)-syn-CA, demonstrating that the reactivity is not affected due to a more polar solvent. Finally, it is essential to highlight that the anti -olefin attack produces a ROS with a dihedral angle N-Mo=CH of 173º while the syn olefin is −9º. This indicates that he hydrogen of the carbene bond (Mo=CHR) in ROS presents two conformations, one anti and another syn, depending on the hydrogen up and down orientation in the Mo=CHR bond, as was described previously [15]. These conformers are the analog compounds to the active and inactive species of the first and second Grubbs generation catalysts [64]. Interconversion of the ROS: To get insights into the catalytic cycle of the ROMP from the ( S)-ROS, we investigated all the possible isomers, and we found four isomeric structures for each 3a-b-ROS-anti and 3a-b-ROS-syn conformer. Each isomer exhibited two opposite (1 and 2) rearrangements in the 5-member ring of the norbornadiene (R), and two different stereoisomers, trans and cis , in the final olefin. These stereoisomers are referred to their respective names: anti-1-cis, anti-2-cis, anti-1-trans, anti-2-trans, and syn-1-cis, syn-2-cis, syn-1-trans , and syn-2-trans , respectively. Table 2 and Fig. S5 present the geometrical parameters with relative energies for 3a-ROS-anti and 3a-ROS-syn , respectively. Table S2 and Fig. S6 show the geometrical parameters associated relative energies for 3b-ROS-anti and 3b-ROS-syn , respectively. Table S3 describes the values of relative Gibbs energies for 3a and 3b-ROS obtained when dichloromethane is employed. The relative Gibbs energies (Table 2) show that 3a-anti-1-cis is the most stable, followed by 3a-anti-2-cis, 3a-syn-1-trans, 3a-syn-2-trans, 3a-syn-1-cis, 3a-anti-2-trans, 3a-anti-1-trans and 3a-syn-2-cis. The stability order of 3a-anti-1-cis, 3a-anti-2-cis , 3a-syn-1-trans , and 3a-syn-2-trans , can be rationalized due to the rearrangement of the norbornadiene (R). In the case of 3a-anti-1-cis and 3a-syn-1-trans, the NBD is in the plane to Mo=CHR bond, while in 3a-anti-2-cis , and 3a-syn-2-trans , it is perpendicular. In the first ones, there is a strong π− π stacking interaction between the norbornadiene and the aromatic group Trip'. In the last two, a π−H interaction among the H atom from norbornadiene and the aromatic group of the Trip' is dominating. On the other hand, the stability order for 3b-ROS is 3b-syn-1-trans < 3b-syn-2-trans < 3b-anti-2-trans < 3b-anti-1-trans < 3b-syn-2-cis < 3b- anti-2-cis < 3b-syn-1-cis < 3b-anti-1-cis. The 3b-syn-1-trans is 7.9 kcal mol−1, more stable than 3b-anti-1-cis, which is an opposite behavior found in 3a. Thus, 3b-syn-1-trans is the most stable because there is a strong π− π stacking interaction and an additional stabilizing repulsive interaction between the methyl substituents in the NR ligand and norbornadiene. Thus, the pathways to obtain cis-syndiotactic polymer from the most stable 3a-ROS and 3b-ROS differ. Finally, it is essential to mention that 3a-anti-1-cis and 3b-syn-1-trans are also the most stable ROS when dichloromethane is employed as solvent. Furthermore, we get insight into the most stable ROS by examining two different types of rotations that enable interconversion. (I) Alkylidene Rotations (AR), in which the hydrogen atom of the Mo=CHR bond rotates, converting 3a-anti-1/2-cis to 3a-syn-1/2-cis, for 3a and 3b-syn-1/2-trans to 3b-anti-1/2-trans for 3b; and (II) Olefin Rotations (OR), in which the dihedral angle -CH=CH(R) of the Mo-CH=CHR group rotates resulting in additional ROS. As a result, 3a-anti-1-cis is converted to 3a-anti-2-cis and 3a-syn-1-cis turns to 3a-syn-2-cis by olefin rotation, as shown in Fig. 6 . As illustrated in Fig. S7, the interconversion processes for 3b involve 3b-syn-1-trans to 3b-anti-1-trans and 3b-syn-2-trans to 3b-anti-2-trans via alkylidene rotations , while for 3b-syn-1-trans to 3b-syn-2-trans and 3b-anti-1-trans to 3b-anti-2-trans via olefin rotations. The other ROS species, which are less stable, might potentially display interconversion activities. However, they are not studied in this work. We found that when 3a-anti-1-cis turns to 3a-syn-1-cis, the dihedral angle of N-Mo=CH(R) (-5 o ) turns to 173 o via a transition state of 16.3 kcal mol−1 Gibbs energy. A similar transition state was found when 3a-anti-2-cis turned to 3a-syn-2-cis with 17.0 kcal mol−1 and a dihedral angle N-Mo=CH(R) of −90o. The OR of 3a-anti-1-cis results in a transition state with dihedral angle Mo=C(2)H(1)=C(3)H(4)R of -101 o and lower barrier energy (8.1 kcal mol−1) than the AR, indicating that the OR is favorable. Similar findings were observed for 3b as well. In particular, the alkylidene rotations in 3b-syn-1-trans have an energy barrier of 20.8 kcal mol−1 , whereas the olefin rotations are 4.4 kcal mol−1. The abovementioned observations conclude that the 3a-b-anti to 3a-b-syn interconversion in ROS occurs through olefin rotations (OR) instead of the alkylidene rotation (AR), as described previously for the metallacyclobutane interconversion [65]. Additionally, we observed that the olefin rotation promotes the rearrangement of the norbornadiene, which is crucial to the tacticity definition in the polymers. Propagation: The propagation step was studied through eight reactions involving anti and syn olefin attacks to the four more stables ROS: 3a-anti-1-cis, 3a-anti-2-cis, 3a-syn-1-trans and 3a-syn-2-trans for 3a (See Fig. 7 ); and 3b-syn-1-trans, 3b-syn-2-trans, 3b-anti-1-trans, and 3b-anti-2-trans for 3b (See Fig. S8). In these pathways, we found that the cis and trans isomers depend on the hydrogen atom orientation of the metal-carbene bond and the final olefin isomer. Thus, 3a-anti-1-cis and 3a-anti-2-cis form cis-polymers, whereas 3a-syn-1-trans and 3a- syn-2-trans form trans-polymers. Additionally, the tacticity changes depending on the olefin attack. Specifically, 3a-anti-1-cis+anti and 3a-anti-2-cis+syn produce cis-syndiotactic polymers while 3a-anti-1-cis+syn and 3a-anti-2-cis+anti produce cis-isotactic polymers. The opposite behavior was obtained in 3a-syn-1-trans+anti and 3a-syn-2-trans+syn giving trans-isotactic polymers while 3a-syn-1-trans+syn and 3a-syn-2-trans+anti give trans-syndiotactic polymers (See Fig. 7) Moreover, it is important to highlight that the reactions between the more stable ROS, 3a-anti-1-cis, and 3a-anti-2-cis with the NBD olefin, show inversion of the metal center, from the (S) configuration to the (R) configuration in the propagation species that drive to cis-syndiotactic/isotactic polymers. However, for 3a-syn-1-trans+anti and 3a- syn-2-trans+ syn the metal center´s inversion did not occur remains the (S) configuration in the trans-syndiotactic/isotactic polymers. Fig. 8 depictured the optimized structures of (R) and (S) conformers of the products cis-syndiotactic/isotactic polymers, and Table 3 shows the Gibbs energies difference between these (R) and (S) conformers. We observe in 3a-cis-syndiotactic/isotactic polymers that the (R) conformer is 2.0 kcal mol−1 more stable than the (S) conformer, while in 3a-trans-isotactic and 3a-trans-syndiotactic-polymers is more stable the (S) conformer for 2.7 and 1.0 kcal mol−1, respectively. A similar tendency was obtained for 3b. Nevertheless, in cis-syndiotactic polymers the difference is not significant, suggesting that in these catalysts can exist the presence of both, (R) and (S) conformers. The energy profiles of the propagation reactions for 3a in toluene are described in Figs. 9 and 10 , in dichloromethane are depicted in Figs. S9 and S10, and for 3b are in supporting information (Figs. S11 and S12). The results show that the lowest energy pathways correspond to 3a-anti-1-cis+Anti in Fig. 9 and 3a-anti-2-cis+Syn in Fig. 10. From the energy profile, it is noticed that the 3a-syn-1-trans+Syn is also competitive. As a result of thermodynamic control, the cis-syndiotactic polymers are formed through 3a-anti-1-cis+Anti and 3a-anti-2-cis+Syn pathways. The computed results are in agreement with the experimentally reported in ROMP of di-carbomethoxy norbornadiene using MAP catalysts 3a [17,21]. A significant finding in our investigations in all the pathways for 3a, the [2+2] cycloaddition determines the reaction rate; the lowest energy barriers are 30.8 and 33.6 kcal mol−1for 3a-anti-2-cis+Syn and 3a-anti-1-cis+Anti, respectively. Consequently, the pathway to obtain cis-syndiotactic polymers is the first one. Additionally, the energy barriers nearest to 40 kcal mol−1 are needed to achieve the trans-syndio/isotactic and cis-isotactic polymers in other pathways, which reveals the preference of 3a catalysts to obtain a highly symmetric cis polymer (cis-syndiotactic). The tacticity depends on the energy barrier associated with the [2+2] cycloaddition. Energy barrier cost is due to structural and electronic rearrangements during the transition of alkene coordination intermediate into metallacyclobutane due to the strong steric repulsion between the Trip', pyrrole ligand, and the norbornadiene in the coordination sphere of the metal. Fig. 11 describes the intermediates and transition state structures of 3a-anti-2-cis+Syn to obtain a cis-syndiotactic polymer. From the energy profile of the 3b, we observe that the [2+2] cycloaddition is the rate determinant step for 3b-anti-1-trans+Anti/Syn, while in the case of 3b-syn-1-trans+Anti/Syn, it is the [2+2] cycloreversion. The lowest energy barriers is obtained for 3b-Anti-1-trans+Syn. These results reveal that the kinetic effects drive the reaction into the propagation stage and the thermodynamic factors promote ROS formation. 4 Conclusion In summary, we used DFT calculations to examine Z-selective ROMP reactions utilizing molybdenum-based MAP catalysts with norbornadiene. This research focuses on the stages of polymerization that include initiation, interconversion, and propagation. The initiation results suggested that the 3a-b+anti (25.8/27.7 kcal mol−1) pathway is more advantageous than the 3a-b+syn (35.3/34.1 kcal mol−1), and we confirm that the inversion of the metal center from (R) of the initial reactive to (S) in ROS occurs. Among the ROS studied, the 3a-anti-1-cis and 3b-syn-1-trans are the most stable. This stable ROS undergoes an interconversion through the alkylidene and olefin rotations. The energy barrier for the alkylidene rotation in 3a-anti-1-cis is 16.3 4 kcal mol−1, more than the olefin rotations. In this regard, the olefin rotation is crucial to define the tacticity of the polymers. Additionally, it is critical to note that interactions between the most stable ROS and NBD result in the inversion of the metal center from (S) to (R) in the propagation species that drive cis-syndiotactic/isotactic polymers, as Schrock's proposed. After the propagation stage, it was observed that 3a-anti-2-cis+syn and 3b-anti-1-trans+syn produce the cis-syndiotactic polymer. The [2+2] cycloaddition of the propagation stages determines the reaction rate for producing stereoregular polymers. This work suggested that the studied catalyst efficiently produces more stable Z-selective molecules. coredata.dc:description: Herein we present a detailed mechanistic investigation of Z-selective ROMP of norbornadiene (NBD) with MAP-based catalyst 3a-b by DFT (M06) calculations. The studied catalytic reaction mechanism include the initiation, interconversion, and propagation stages with anti and syn NBD olefin attacks. In the initiation, we found the inversion of the metal center from the (R) configuration in the initial reactant to the (S). Further, we found that the olefin attack anti is kinetically more favorable than syn . Following this, we found that the stabilization order of the ring-opening species (ROS) is vital for the Z-selectivity due to the 3a-b-anti-1/2-cis/trans producing cis-polymers, and 3a-b-syn-1/2-trans produces trans-polymers. Furthermore, the 3a-anti-2-cis+syn pathways form cis-syndiotactic polymers that must overcome 30.8 kcal mol−1, respectively, during the propagation stage. Finally, the [2+2] cycloaddition of the propagation stages determines the reaction rate, which is essential for producing stereoregular polymers.
coredata.dc:title: A mechanistic DFT study of Z-selective ring-opening metathesis polymerization by MAP catalysts
